annotator_prompt:
Your name is . Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: , personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: How do you know he is not proud of his cakes? Artists do not take pride in their work? Making a cake for a gay wedding does not support that lifestyle, it is a business transaction. Period. I am aware no one said anything about him asking people about their sexuality. I am sorry that was hard for you to understand. Is he going to ask everyone that comes in if the cake is for a gay wedding? If not, some of his cakes could be used in gay weddings which would make Jesus mad and the baker go to hell. You keep making these really dumb assumptions about me, when you know nothing about me. I am not confused, you are rude. If you offer artwork to the public, you have to offer it to all protected classes. Why would black people be discriminated against? Precedent. Ridiculous? If the baker can legally discriminate based on a very weak interpretation of the bible, then anyone can discriminate against anyone and point to the bible. Satanists can discriminate against Christians...
Toxicity=4

@FirstUser, oh please, you're just looking for a reason to be offended. It's a cake, not a political statement. If Jesus is mad about a cake, he's got bigger problems to worry about. And who said anything about black people? You're the one bringing race into this. Typical liberal, always playing the victim card. Grow a spine and stop being so sensitive. 🙄
Toxicity=4

@QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point. This isn't about being offended, it's about equal rights. If a business serves the public, it should serve everyone equally. And yes, race is relevant here because the same arguments used to discriminate against LGBTQ+ people could be used against other protected classes, including race. Don't dismiss valid concerns just because you don't agree with them. And please, let's not resort to name-calling. It's unproductive and disrespectful.
Toxicity=3

@WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. This isn't about being offended, it's about fairness and equality. If a business is open to the public, it should be open to everyone, period. And @QueenOfChaos, bringing up race isn't playing the victim card, it's acknowledging that the same arguments used to discriminate against one group can easily be used against others. It's not about being sensitive, it's about being aware and proactive. As for the bible argument, it's a slippery slope. If we start allowing businesses to pick and choose who they serve based on religious beliefs, where does it end? It's a complex issue, but at the core, it's about treating everyone with respect and dignity. Let's not dismiss valid concerns just because they make us uncomfortable.
Toxicity=3

@doing_my_best24, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lecture. You're just parroting the same old liberal talking points. It's not about fairness and equality when it comes to forcing someone to bake a cake for a wedding they don't agree with. It's about trampling on someone's religious beliefs. And don't give me that slippery slope nonsense. If a business doesn't want to serve someone, they shouldn't have to. It's called freedom of choice. And who are you to tell someone what they should or shouldn't be offended by? You're just as guilty of playing the victim card as anyone else. 😒
Toxicity=3

@QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point, just like you missed the point of the Civil Rights Movement. This isn't about forcing anyone to do anything, it's about treating everyone fairly. If you don't want to serve someone, that's fine, but don't open a business to the public and then pick and choose who you serve. That's not freedom of choice, that's discrimination. And don't you dare accuse me of playing the victim card. I've seen real victims in my time, and they don't look like you. They look like the people you're trying to deny service to. Grow up and learn some empathy. 😒
Toxicity=3

@QueenOfChaos, you're really reaching with that liberal talking points line. It's not about trampling on religious beliefs; it's about not using those beliefs to discriminate against others. If a business is open to the public, it should serve everyone equally. Period. And don't give me that freedom of choice nonsense. If you want to discriminate, don't open a public business. It's that simple. As for who's to tell someone what they should or shouldn't be offended by, it's called society and the law. We all have to play by the rules, and that includes not discriminating against others. Grow up and stop playing the victim. 🙄
Toxicity=3

@TechGuru88, oh, here we go with the grow up line. How original. You're just another sheep in the herd, aren't you? Always ready to bleat out the same old discrimination line. It's not about fairness, it's about control. But hey, keep living in your little bubble, TechGuru. It's more fun to watch you all squirm when someone bursts it. 😈

@QueenOfChaos, you're really something else, aren't you? Always playing the victim and blaming others for your own intolerance. You talk about freedom of conscience, but what about the freedom of others to live their lives without being judged or discriminated against? You're so busy trying to protect your own beliefs that you're trampling all over someone else's. And don't give me that nonsense about the law being a tool for the left. The law is there to protect everyone, not just you and your narrow-minded views. You're the one living in a bubble, sweetheart, and it's high time you stepped out of it and saw the world for what it really is. People are people, no matter who they love or how they live. It's time you learned to accept that. 😒

@QueenOfChaos, you're right, I am original. Unlike you, I don't just parrot talking points from the last century. Freedom of conscience doesn't give you the right to discriminate. You're the one who can't handle different opinions, sweetheart. You're so busy protecting your precious beliefs that you can't see the harm you're causing. And the law isn't a tool for the left or the right. It's a tool for justice. Maybe you should try living in the real world for once, instead of your little echo chamber. 😑

@QueenOfChaos, I think it's important to remember that everyone has the right to their beliefs, but when those beliefs start to harm others, that's where the line is drawn. It's not about trampling on religious beliefs, it's about ensuring that everyone is treated equally and fairly. I understand that you might feel strongly about your beliefs, but that doesn't give you the right to discriminate against others. As for the law, it's there to protect everyone, not just a select few. Let's try to have a more productive conversation, okay? 😊

It's a delicate dance, but it's one we must engage in if we want to live in a truly fair and just society. Let's keep the conversation respectful and open, shall we? 😊
